posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
I’m excited to announce Luma P1, the first product from Luma Vision . The Luma P1 is an affordable, high-performance AprilTag smart camera designed to lower the barrier of entry to “plug-and-play” AprilTag localization.

P1 1920×1440 45.3 KB

P1 1920×1440 45.3 KB

P1 1920×1440 45.3 KB

Buck-Boost power stage 3.3V - 22.5V Input range Reverse voltage protection PoE + Weidmuller power input

3.3V - 22.5V Input range

Reverse voltage protection

PoE + Weidmuller power input

Powered by Raspberry Pi CM5

Actively cooled to eliminate thermal throttling and maintain maximum performance

Integrated, pre-focused OV9281 global shutter monochrome camera Up to 1280x800 at 120fps capture 80 degree horizontal FOV 56 degree vertical FOV

Up to 1280x800 at 120fps capture

80 degree horizontal FOV

56 degree vertical FOV

USB 3 port for additional external cameras/USB devices

3D printed PA-CF enclosure

Individual components will be available for purchase to support repairability

Luma Vision is committed to using open-source software in all of its products. Therefore, Luma P1 runs PhotonVision , the open-source, community developed vision solution trusted by the FRC community for years.

Integrated camera at 1280x800: 60-70fps

Integrated camera at 1280x800 + external OV9281 at 640x480: 40-50fps each

Integrated camera at 1280x800 + external OV9281 at 1280x800: 40fps internal, 25-30fps external

Tests run with PhotonVision v2025.3.1’s 3D AprilTag pipeline at decimate 2.

Luma P1 will launch before the end of the year at a price of $249.99 USD. Spare components will become available shortly after these units ship.

A limited number of units will be available for pre-order this Sunday, October 5th, at 3PM Eastern. They are expected to start shipping before the end of the month. As a special thank you for giving early feedback on P1, anyone who purchases one of these units will receive a buy one get one free discount code when P1 fully launches later this year. For this initial availability, orders will be limited to a max of 2 devices per order, and will only ship to the U.S. and Canada.

P1 will be available at https://luma.vision . You can sign up to be notified when they go in stock here .
Thank you!!! POE AND ACTIVE COOLING!!!

posts.name: meer
posts.cooked: can u share the dimensions of the p1?

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
72.2mm X 44.2mm X ~37.8mm 2.84in X 1.74in X ~1.5in

This is including the camera lens so the depth may not be exact.

I’ll have documentation available soon with CAD, mounting hole info etc.

posts.name: Joey Tidrow
posts.cooked: I absolutely love this! What were some of the reasons you chose to use a RPI CM5 versus something like a OrangePi CM5 that uses the RK3588?

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked: I originally started with an RK3588 module, but found the software/documentation for the flashing process very, very bad. So not something I wanted to be a user-facing process. The Pi modules are also much lower cost so I could keep the cost of P1 as low as possible. Still definitely something I’m interested in doing.

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: Just wondering, are there also instructions as for how to make this at home, or is it only provided as the product itself?

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked: I eventually want something like repair guides that could serve that purpose.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Given the carbon-fiber filament enclosure, I trust you’ve taken steps to ensure electrical isolation to prevent shorts through the case? Personally I’m always a bit hesitant to use CF filaments anywhere near electronics.

posts.name: dirtbikerxz
posts.cooked:
mjansen4857:

Integrated, pre-focused OV9281

How are they being pre-focused? Is every one set to the same pre-defined focus, or each one individually tested and focused? If it’s the former do the variances in each lens and sensor cause enough of a difference that teams would want to manually refocus each one for optimal results?

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
cbale2000:

I trust you’ve taken steps to ensure electrical isolation to prevent shorts through the case?

Yes, it is isolated from the enclosure.

dirtbikerxz:

How are they being pre-focused?

Individually tested and glued.

posts.cooked:
vince 500×714 78 KB

vince 500×714 78 KB

vince 500×714 78 KB

link_counts.title: Orange Pi alternative for photonvision hardware

posts.name: Andrew Pranger
posts.cooked: This looks incredible! I can’t wait to see how these integrate into the FRC community this season. Curious, what is the return policy for purchases?

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
Another_Person1:

Will there be a fan grate and m.2 slot on the back?

No M.2

Fan is on the back but airflow has a dedicated channel in the enclosure so any debris can’t get to the electronics.

AndrewPranger:

Curious, what is the return policy for purchases?

I don’t have anything concrete posted ATM, but I will generally be as accommodating as possible. So, returns will be accepted for any reason as long as it’s “reasonable”. By this I mean I don’t intend to accept returns of devices used for a whole season or something lol. For hardware issues, I will prefer to send replacement components if the problem can be confirmed to be a specific component, but will still replace the device if necessary or preferred.

This is cool.

To make plug and play better you should consider

Precalibrating each unit in addition to prefocusing.

Give every unit you make an additional unique mdns so that a team can order 2, plug them both into a robot, and access the website of both. Ex. Your 94th unit will have addresses lumavision.local and lumavision94.local.

Imo that’s worth a slightly increased price

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
For #2 , there are rumors of PV looking to solve that more generally with an app running on Systemcore to identify (and perhaps uniquely assign) each coprocessor on the network. Just one more season

Excited to see this new hardware in action!

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
Vasista:

Precalibrating each unit in addition to prefocusing.

I think camera calibration is an important skill that teams should understand how to do and do frequently instead of trusting a factory calibration to remain good forever and then just end up getting worse results over time.

Vasista:

Give every unit you make an additional unique mdns so that a team can order 2, plug them both into a robot, and access the website of both. Ex. Your 94th unit will have addresses lumavision.local and lumavision94.local.

There’s nothing readable in software that identifies the serial number of each device, so any of this config would be lost when flashing. So, an identifier app as mentioned above might be a better bet.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: Do camera calibrations meaningfully change over time at all (assuming the same focus)?

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
I’m super interested.   We were gearing up to design a 3D printed housing for a very similar tech stack, and here you are solving the problem for us!

Maybe consider an optional (TPU?) lens shroud?

For anyone interested in purchasing P1 later this year, please sign up for the in stock notifications.…
